Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a larger piston (A) is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston (a), resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Scene Overview :
  â€¢ The image shows a U-shaped container filled with liquid, with two vertical cylinders attached at each end.
  â€¢ The left cylinder is wider and labeled "A" with a piston on top, upon which a downward force "F" is applied.
  â€¢ The right cylinder is narrower and labeled "a" with a piston on top, upon which a downward force "f" is applied.
  â€¢ The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating equilibrium.
  â€¢ The diagram is labeled "Ø´ÙƒÙ„ Û²" (Figure 2 in Persian/Arabic numerals).

Technical Details :
  â€¢ No scale bar or units are provided.
  â€¢ The pistons are depicted as flat disks fitting tightly in their respective cylinders.
  â€¢ The forces "F" and "f" are shown as arrows pointing downward on the pistons.

Spatial Relationships :
  â€¢ The left piston (A) is much larger in area than the right piston (a).
  â€¢ The liquid connects both pistons, allowing force transmission.
  â€¢ The dashed line indicates equal liquid levels, signifying pressure balance.

Analysis :
  â€¢ The figure visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  â€¢ The difference in piston areas (A > a) suggests that a small force "f" on the small piston can balance a much larger force "F" on the large piston, or vice versa, depending on the direction of force application.
  â€¢ This setup is foundational for understanding hydraulic lifts and presses. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.472,r=0.278,b=0.611), with ID 865a84de-6e2b-475f-a642-d4d06f68c08c -->

Summary : This figure compares the pressure relationships in hydraulic systems with pistons at different levels, illustrating the effect of height difference on pressure transmission and the resulting equations.

illustration:
# Pistons at Different Levels :
â€¢ The left and center panels show two pistons (1 and 2) in a U-shaped tube containing fluid, with piston 1 at a lower level than piston 2.
â€¢ Both panels indicate an applied force f on piston 1 (area a) and a force F on piston 2 (area A).
â€¢ The height difference between the pistons is labeled h.
â€¢ The pressure at each piston is denoted as Pâ‚ and Pâ‚‚.
â€¢ The pressure equality is written as Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
â€¢ The pressure equation is given as: f/a = F/A + Ïgh, where Ï is fluid density and g is gravitational acceleration.

# Pistons at the Same Level :
â€¢ The right panel shows both pistons at the same horizontal level in the fluid.
â€¢ Forces f and F are applied to pistons 1 and 2, respectively.
â€¢ The pressure equality is Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
â€¢ The pressure equation simplifies to: f/a = F/A.

# Equations and Annotations :
â€¢ The equations are shown below each diagram, with the additional Ïgh term present only when the pistons are at different heights.
â€¢ Arabic text labels the scenarios: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†" (pistons at different levels) and "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙŠ" (pistons at the same horizontal level).

Analysis :
â€¢ The figure visually demonstrates that when pistons are at different heights, the pressure transmission includes a hydrostatic term (Ïgh), while at the same level, the pressure is transmitted directly according to the ratio of forces to areas.
â€¢ This highlights the importance of height differences in hydraulic systems and the application of Pascal's principle. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.108,t=0.651,r=0.888,b=0.892), with ID eedeec69-002b-43df-8e39-ee0b0bbf00e3 -->

Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Scene Overview :
  â€¢ The image shows a U-shaped container filled with liquid, with two vertical cylinders of different diameters attached to each end.
  â€¢ The left cylinder is larger, labeled "A" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "F" applied.
  â€¢ The right cylinder is smaller, labeled "a" (area) with a piston on top, and a downward force "f" applied.
  â€¢ The liquid level is the same on both sides, indicating equilibrium.
  â€¢ The diagram is labeled in Persian as "Ø´Ú©Ù„ Û²" (Figure 2).

Technical Details :
  â€¢ No scale bar or units are provided.
  â€¢ Forces are denoted by "F" (large piston) and "f" (small piston).
  â€¢ Areas are denoted by "A" (large piston) and "a" (small piston).
  â€¢ The pistons are shown as solid disks fitting tightly in the cylinders.

Spatial Relationships :
  â€¢ The large piston (left) and small piston (right) are connected by the liquid in the U-tube.
  â€¢ The pistons are at the same vertical height, indicating balanced pressures.

Analysis :
  â€¢ The illustration visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  â€¢ The system demonstrates how a small force applied to a small area can balance a larger force applied to a larger area, or vice versa, depending on the ratio of areas (F/A = f/a).

Summary : This figure compares the pressure relationships and force equations for two pistons in a U-tube hydraulic system, considering cases where the pistons are at different and the same horizontal levels.

illustration:
# Left and Middle Panels: Pistons at Different Levels :
  â€¢ Both panels show a U-tube filled with liquid, with two pistons (labeled 1 and 2) of different cross-sectional areas (a and A) placed on each arm.
  â€¢ The left panel shows piston 1 lower than piston 2; the middle panel shows piston 1 higher than piston 2.
  â€¢ Forces f and F are applied to pistons 1 and 2, respectively.
  â€¢ The height difference between the pistons is denoted as h.
  â€¢ The pressure equality is stated as Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The force relationship is given as:  
    f/a = F/A + Ïgh (left panel)  
    f/a + Ïgh = F/A (middle panel)

# Right Panel: Pistons at the Same Level :
  â€¢ Both pistons are at the same horizontal level in the U-tube.
  â€¢ Forces f and F are applied to pistons 1 and 2, respectively.
  â€¢ The pressure equality is stated as Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ The force relationship is given as:  
    f/a = F/A

# Headings and Annotations :
  â€¢ Top left and middle: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†" (The pistons at different levels)
  â€¢ Top right: "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙ€ÙˆÙ‰ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙŠ" (The pistons at the same horizontal level)
  â€¢ Variables: f (force on small piston), F (force on large piston), a (area of small piston), A (area of large piston), h (height difference), Ï (liquid density), g (acceleration due to gravity).

# Analysis :
  â€¢ When the pistons are at different heights, the pressure difference due to the liquid column (Ïgh) must be included in the force balance.
  â€¢ When the pistons are at the same level, the force-to-area ratio is equal for both pistons, illustrating Pascal's principle in its simplest form.
